title: How to Catch Trout
original_title: How to catch trout in stocked lakes & ponds!!!
content: what's up you guys Timmy bangers here today is April 15 2016 and we're out here at Virgin run lake and today I'm going to show you how I fish a lake like this for stock trout I have with me on my rod this is a the rods and ugly stick elite 7-foot graphite rod medium light the reel is a Shimano similar symmetry 2500 I'm running eight pound mainline on this set up just because I use this for I also use this for other other things but if you're just using trout you can go as light as six pound or four pound if you even have a lighter rod like an ultra light but what I like to do is put a slip sinker on my mainline this is a one ounce egg sinker tied to a bead to protect the knot and then tied to a swivel and then from the swivel this is where I put on my four pound fluorocarbon leader anywhere from 16 to 24 inches this one's a little longer because we have to float this power bait up above the grass there's a lot of grass in this lake I have a size 10 bait holder hook and I have power bait covering the hook completely in the shape of like a hatchery pallet like these fish would be used to eat the power bait on using is gulp natural garlic scent chunky cheese now personal preference what color and flavor you use depends on what they want that time of year but since it's early and they're going to be used to eat and hatchery pellets which are brown I'm going with this and this water is not too dirty it's pretty clear so I think that'll be just fine today and I'm going to add some more flavor to that by using bite on garlic trout attractant this is a garlic flavored it's a you could dip your power bait in or you could squirt it in there or spray it on the bait I mean so that's what I'm going to do I'm going to shake it up put some couple drops on now this power baits already garlic scented so this is just going to spike it up even more and I'm not done yet on to that I'm going to add lip rippers hatchery dust and since that is now wet with that garlic scent liquid we're going to roll it around in this I'm going to get it is covered up as much as you can and that is what you're left with that's what we're going to throw out there and we're going to see how long it takes now this stuff's probably just going to come off most of it but it's still going to put that scent out and that's what you want all right we'll just go past this straight out and see how long it takes to get a bite now the lines out there just going to take a float pull my line down and this way we can watch the one when the bomber starts to move go up when a fish bites the ball will go up like this then you know time to set the hook all right we're going to let that go and see how long it takes right now it's 341 so let's see how long it takes to get a bite all right I'll be back with you guys in a minute all right look at this I always want to wet your hands if you're going to be releasing you don't want to take that slime off of their body he's a wiggler all right nice hook set in the corner of the mouth comes out very easily look at that that is a very nice rainbow stock rainbow and I'm just going to let him go right there we don't want to keep them out of the water too long and there he goes perfect catch and release for stock trout all right guys stay tuned

make that an hour and almost an hour and a half of daylight left before it gets dark and that's the perfect time we're targeting salmon and I'll show you my setup here at this time of year you can catch salmon you catch trout we're really trying to hook it to the salmon today and I've got to set up here with my favorite the swivel as you know the t-turn swivel off to a hook and I'm going to on this hook I've got a nice jar of Roe bags here that Antonio did up for us and I'm going to put that row bag right there on that hook just like that nicely and then as a little teaser on the top I have another T turn and I've got a nice trembler fly here it's a trembler by Big John died that for me especially for today and what I like to do with my flies put a little bit of scent on them and they will just absorb that scent any any kind of scent if you have a game fish scent that will be ideal but that scent is just perfect and the salmon will hone in on that and good strike on it so it gives me a couple of chances and because we're only out here for an hour and change I've got my bait caster here as well this is setup regs and ready to go in case I get hung up I don't want to waste the time rereading so this one doesn't have it we're on it but it's ready to go if need be and when we're fishing here we're really not ditional far it's relatively deep so I've got a heavy sinker on there and he with that heavy sinker is it's going to get me down there this is a strong current they want that sinker to keep me in place and unlike fishing in a boat where you got to move around this time of year all you want to do is stay stationary the salmon are moving up from Lake Ontario they're moving up these creeks and rivers and they're in here to spawn basically they come to spawn and die that's what they're going to do and so they're constantly on the move and they're going upstream so all you have to do is stay in one spot and just wait for the salmon to come by and we're hoping to do just that so stay tuned folks between me and Antonio we're hoping to have a great hour on the water there's one there's one like that oh just like that folks I got a scream rods unbelievable Oh fish you definitely want to make sure you've got a good size reel with a lot of line because as you just seen there oh they're just screaming and I've got that dragged on tight my goodness this is no place for a smaller reel and the other thing I'm doing I've got braided line on here and the braided line the advantage of a braided line is that you can put a lot more line onto your spool so if you do have a smaller reel I had to tell you this thing's really strong if you do have a smaller reel at least with the braided line it will allow you to hook and into and it allow you to spool up with a lot more line I got a friendly angler here on shore helping me out here this is what we ended up landing right there at an absolute beautiful round throat it's not a salmon but it's a great start to our day we just just started fishing in the water for maybe less than a minute and what a great bite that was and what an absolute beautiful fish that is right there so we're going to get back in there I really want to get into some salmon action and the nights just started so with any luck we'll get into a few more fish but what a great start to our day right there love that backhoe they go like I say we're not casting out that far and the salmon and the TRO obviously they'll follow the shoreline they'll come nice and close especially as it gets darker here it's no problem to the fish close to the shoreline they're not as afraid they'll come right up and you'll see them jump in close by - so well folks here's your half-hour update as you see this rods got two teachers on it and no sinker and no hook I got into a snag it's been a half an hour and I'm switching over to my other rod with just the row bag and we'll get it back out there but I got to tell you the reason I like that original setup with the row bag on the bottom and that trembler on the top it's not because I caught a fish right away mind you that's your help but main reason is because that row bag is down along the bottom and it's hovering around the bottom and that that trembler was a little bit higher up top and the trembler with this current is just going to be waving around in there so I'm covering both avenues there I'm covering the very bottom and I'm covering a little bit higher and we'll salmon there moving along the bottom and they're coming up and jumping and the whole key to that setup is those key turns that are the T turns the t turns keep you 100 at tangle-free while you're fishing out there allows Meru bank to spin around the rosettes that streamer fly that trembler just to move around in the water and it will help trigger bite because these salmon aren't really feeding right now they're moving up river to spawn and they're not really on the bite but they're always enticed by a little row bag and in fact if you use a spoon like the the Python tartar or if you use a crankbait or an inline spinner the salmon will hit those two but I think they hit them more out of spike than they do out of hunger to natural reef reflex to them but the other thing I'd like to say we've got about another 20 minutes here even if you don't fish it's worth a walk in the fall if there's a river or a creek off the Lake Ontario and just watching the salmon jump because they really put on a great show and I'm hoping the hook into one more fish here myself or Antonio before the end of the day and like I said I think we have about 20 minutes of that's quarter to seven right now they said the sun's going down at 7:00 may get another five or ten minutes after sundown but we'll see how it goes I did want to say one more thing I always keep my rod in the ready position fishing from shore like this and I'm still fishing they keep it right there in that position and in a great position to set the hook as opposed to keeping your rod tilted in a higher position this is the perfect position right there all I'm doing now is just waiting for that pike which in the past half hour I must say I did I got snagged up on the one and I did have another bite that I hold and missed on he just as I finished saying hopefully we'll get into another bite here Antonio set the hook and he reeled that fish in before he even had a chance to get the camera it's a bow the little rain boy oh that's a beautiful nice little fish right there Antonio took the row bag took the reel well we didn't have too bad of a day coming here for a little time like so a nice brown trout a nice little rainbow had one other bite but we just couldn't entice the salmon to fighting and like I say they typically not on the on the bite right now this time of year but it sure would have been nice to in face intubating but i got to tell you what a relaxed will night an hour and change out here on the water absolutely love it I want to thank you so much for tuning in folks that thundermans fishing tips always nice to spend time with you and that's always until next time good luck

title: How to Catch Trout
original_title: How to Catch, Clean and Cook a Trout, Montana Style
content: so here we are in Big Sky Montana it's an amazing place we're here for our family vacation and this year I went fly-fishing - the first time I went to this place I didn't but this guy told me and I caught some fish very first day of fly-fishing it is unbelievably fun I did keep one to eat so I'm going to show you how to cook a trout here's how you do it to clean your fish first cut off the head right near the skull all the way around then get out all the intestines and stomach and stuff by cutting a foot along the bottom of scraping it out now along the backbone there's a little blood vessel you gonna break that and scrape all that out as well rinse it off and then you're all set cleaned fish then in a frying pan melt a little butter over medium heat take your trout dredge it in flour and then you're gonna fry it in the butter for about three minutes each side you know put it on a plate and you're gonna peel off the bone for using a fork to remove all the meat from the bones first one side easy for me to say then the other this way you get hardly any bones while you're eating it a fish skeleton we got all the bones out in one piece then just add a little salt and pepper a little butter if you want and you're good to go Montana is an amazing place we're staying at this place called Sky house it's in Big Sky so if you're looking for a vacation place consider this because there's lots to do here we do Pikes with Yellowstone's Old Faithful we saw bears we saw elk some moose we saw mountain goats we went swimming in a boiling River there's so much to do here this is an amazing and remarkable part of the country so you haven't been on my Montana check it out you're looking for a place to stay check out sky house we'll put the link in the description so that's how you cook a trout especially in Montana trout that I conned my first day of fly-fishing running dry Barrett you're watching cooking for dads cook well it is worth it

title: How to Catch Trout

content: hi doing guys Malik over at modern pawn today we're going to be talking about croaker fishing it's springtime those big styles are running through the grass flats and the croaker are in season down here in South Texas there's croaker at the bait stand if you guys have never fished croaker it is a different way of fishing from what we normally do the majority of the year but it is it's pretty fun and you have a chance of catching some really big trout so I'm talking some some big logs and big big 30-inch trout are normally caught on on live croaker and we're going to go over some of the reasons why we fish croaker why the trout hit croaker and the way in which we catch him looking fish croaker fish undisclosed location the first thing we're going to talk about is why fish a live croaker a live croaker is not just a food source for trout it's not like fishing a dead cut bait a live shrimp or anything like that I mean cut crab any of those kinds of things that people fish for inshore species the croaker is a natural enemy to the trout especially large female spawning trout what happens is those big trout in the springtime will swim up into shallow grass flats they'll swim up from deeper water into a grassy transition to spawn and what they're doing is they're they're going in there they're interested in finding a spot to lay their eggs they're not in there gorging on finger mullet they're not in there looking for shrimp they're not feeding per se now they do eat obviously but they're in there to spawn take it easy big girl croaker are natural enemies to the trowel they eat trout eggs female trout know this if a female trout is in a grass flat looking for a place to spawn or she's currently spawning putting eggs here putting eggs there and she here's a trap she hears a croaker making his little croaker noise that's why we call him a croaker it's cuz they grunt they make a little grunting croaker noise if she hears that she will come to that fish they will bite that fish that will grab ahold of that fish if they're hungry or if they're not hungry it really is almost irrelevant if they're feeding or not they're in there to drop those eggs and they're protecting those eggs so the croaker bite on it from a trowel is generally a defensive bite not necessarily an opportunistic feeding bite there's a type of hook called a croaker hook a lot of companies when you buy it on the package it actually says croaker hook it's also called a kale hook kale with a K I think this is a 4 OTT I've seen them 3 out of 4 out 5 off all the way up to a 6 on we I will carry a couple of different size croaker hook depending on how big the average Coker is that we get from the baits and sometimes you get these croaker and they're they're like six six inch croaker and sometimes you get them in there 2 inch croaker so we normally size this style of hook to the appropriate size croaker that are in the live well sometimes you get a mixed bag the for our croaker hook seems to work cover everything cover all our bases I generally throw thirty pound fluorocarbon I might throw 40 pound fluorocarbon if I feel like there's some extra oyster eat oysters in the bottom or are some instructions or I feel like I might get to start getting a braided on my tie on 40 pound fluorocarbon but generally thirty pound fluorocarbon is what we use these are here are just basic egg weights sliding egg weights these are faceted glass beads you don't have to necessarily get the faceted ones you don't necessarily have to get red really what you want is just glass beads and what we use these beads with in conjunction with the egg weights is a it helps the egg way from slipping over the knot and B it provides a little bit of a click clicking noise the other thing that we will throw or we're called chatter weights and what these are are they're weighted they're not ultra super heavy like an open lead egg but they are weighted and they have a rattle in them some of them rattle a little more than others and I have a couple of different sizes all the way up to some some bigger ones like this and what this does is again we're drawing attention to where our Croker are as also a weight helps bring that croaker down to the bottom it helps keep your bait in place if there's any current there's any wind so this this generally we can you use a combination of any of this bait sometimes we'll throw a small chatter and a small egg weight chatter only any weight only just kind of depends on how much current we have pulling through there how thick the grass is as well what I did was I tied my suffix braid to a chatter wait I don't know if you can hear that chatter wait then I tied for carbon and I put about maybe six inches on this one with a sliding egg weight and a glass bead and the glass bead in this situation is really just to keep my egg weight from sliding that far forward all the way to the hook and when I have here I put a nail knot in the middle that this this egg weight stops on that bead on that on that nail knot and so there is a little bit of movement of the egg weight this one's about maybe twenty four inches of the thirty pound fluorocarbon and and then we had the hook tied on to the end about the anal fin right below the lateral line on a croaker hook and that's what you want right there little little egg weight spinning rails versus bait casters both can work both have their advantages spinning reels we use spinning rails and bait casters there's another type of reel that's the that it's kind of a blend of the two it's called a bait runner spinning reel it's a spinning reel that has a bait runner function on it the real advantage to bait casters is the fact that you could open the spool very quick and easy with the push of the thumb button opening of the spool what that does is it allows that trout to take the croaker you could push that button and the line will peal out with little almost no resistance and then as soon as you're ready to set the hook all you have to do is click it and you're fighting the fish spinning rails to get the same kind of effect you generally have to open the bail you open the bail let the fish take the the line then you got to either flip the bail over manually or if you have a reel where you can just turn the handle and then we'll close the bail automatically the third type of reel is a bait casting spinning reel or a bait runner style spinning reel and what this is it's basically a standard spinning reel has your drag up here but it has a second drag system right here and it's a bait running drag system when you do with this as you flip this guy off now the line comes out very easily and you have some control over it down here on how much drag is on the secondary drag so you can keep the bail closed while the fish is taking your bait and as soon as you go to turn the handle it disengages the light drag Andry engages the stiff drag and now you're back to your six pounds of drag or whatever you're running on the reel so there's there's a few different ways of doing it but the way that we catch the the Croke with the trout on the croaker is the same every time okay guys we're going to mock up for you like we're catching we're catching fish on croaker basically you're going to cast the rod as soon as that croaker hits the water you're going to leave the spool open for a second let them get down to the bottom let them get oriented you're going to let them make sure that there's actual slack in the line so there's all the way down that he's oriented as soon as he's as soon as you give him maybe a five count you're going to click the bail and you're going to real up until there you feel that there's just light tension in the line if you get good croaker from the based and they're still going to be lively you'll be able to feel I'm just kind of jiggling on there they'll be wiggling their tail that's what you want once we have them in that position I'm going to let out a lot offline so that my rod tip is relatively straight up and down I don't want my rod tip out pointed towards the fish I want it real high almost at a 12 o'clock position okay what you're going to do from this point what we do is we keep the bail open so we keep the spool in the in the click position we keep it here and I leave my thumb on the reel to have some sensitivity from this point what we're going to do it just on occasion I'm talking maybe every 60 seconds is give that croaker a little don't thump-thump-thump wake him up make sure he's that he's not grassed up make sure there's a bait there see if I can feel them swimming what's going to happen when you feel that croaker get hit by the trout you're going to feel it bolt you're going to feel like a little bump up as soon as you feel it what we do we drop the rod and we let our finger off the spool okay and what you're going to see is that trout is going to start peeling that line off they're going to start taking it and you're going to want to just go bill dance on them that's not what you want to do the instinct is just to jerk back work hard on it what I see guys do is they as soon as they feel that bump they weigh em they slam and turn rip that trout's head off all you're going to do is pull the croaker out of the trout's mouth what that trout is doing he's biting that croaker normally on the belly or the back and he's going to swim and then he's going to move the croaker around until he gets a head first and eat it so you got to give them some time and and sometimes you need to give them lots of time I've had times where the guys that were given like ten counts we're catching the fish and then sometimes you know you dill they're picking them up and they're swallowing on them real fast you'll know because they'll take off real hot and heavy and even if you give them a little line you'll still catch them so you're going to let them take that five count off there then what we're going to do is we're going to click the bail and just lift up and they should be on there because if he's pulling line there's tension on that line so I don't need to I don't need that wham and slamming real hard all you're going to do is if they don't have it properly positioned in their mouth is that you're just going to jerk it away from them now sometimes on the
